body:
Comment 1: 
Go strings can carry any sequence of bytes. A zero byte is nothing special (at runtime
within a string, not in Go source code). It is legal to use strings for general binary
data (just any non UTF-8 necoding as well). Of course then string handling functions may
not work. But if `TrimSpace()` should trim also zero bytes then it should have be
instead named `TrimSpaceAndzeros` or something like that.

IMO "Working as intended".
